text:
U.S.-based energy company EOG Resources has secured a Certificate of Environmental Clearance to drill two offshore gas exploration wells in Trinidad. Issued by the Environmental Management Authority (EMA), the approval covers the TG1 and TG2 wells located in the NCMA 4(a) Unlimited Block off the country’s north coast.

The clearance follows a comprehensive regulatory review of the proposed drilling program, including operational timelines, vessel logistics, support activities and a conceptual waste management plan. The EMA also assessed potential environmental impacts associated with the offshore campaign before issuing approval.

According to EMA Chairman Doolar Ramlal, the clearance was granted within the statutory timeframe, underscoring the authority’s commitment to efficient regulatory oversight. He noted that the decision supports Trinidad and Tobago’s development objectives while maintaining environmental protection standards.

The approval marks a key step in advancing EOG’s offshore gas exploration plans in Trinidad, reinforcing continued upstream activity in one of the Caribbean’s most established gas-producing markets.

title: Nigerian Researcher Leads Innovative Study on Sustainable Aviation Fuel Emissions
description:
Her research focuses on understanding turbine engine emissions produced when SAFs and SAF–jet fuel blends are combusted, and how these emissions may influence human health outcomes among aviation personnel.
The study is one of the emerging efforts in the United States to link aviation decarbonization strategies with worker health.
Her interest in the topic reflects a broader scientific trajectory rooted in environmental health and exposure science.
Through her work on SAF emissions, she highlights the importance of including occupational health considerations in national and international aviation sustainability agendas.
The findings from her study are expected to contribute to ongoing discussions by research boards, regulatory agencies, and technical committees working toward safer and cleaner aviation systems.
text:
In recent years, the global aviation sector has faced mounting pressure to reduce its environmental footprint while safeguarding the health of the workers who support its operations. Against this backdrop, Onyinye Ezeifeka, a Nigerian doctoral researcher specializing in industrial hygiene and air quality assessment at the University of Cincinnati, USA, has emerged as one of the early-career scientists investigating how the transition to Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAFs) could shape occupational exposures in aviation environments.

Her research focuses on understanding turbine engine emissions produced when SAFs and SAF–jet fuel blends are combusted, and how these emissions may influence human health outcomes among aviation personnel. The work is part of a broader scientific effort to evaluate whether SAFs, widely promoted for their ability to reduce lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions, also lead to measurable improvements in near-field air quality for workers such as aircraft mechanics, ground crew, and fuel handlers.

Ezeifeka’s project integrates aerosol science, occupational exposure assessment, and combustion chemistry. Working within the University of Cincinnati’s Safe Air Lab, she examines particle size distributions, organic pollutant composition, and toxicological profiles of emissions generated from controlled turbine engine combustion scenarios using laboratory-grade SAF samples. Her team employs advanced aerosol measurement tools, including the Fast Mobility Particle Sizer (FMPS), Optical Particle Sizer (OPS), and other real-time monitoring instruments, to characterize nanoparticulates and volatile organic compounds formed during SAF combustion.

The study is one of the emerging efforts in the United States to link aviation decarbonization strategies with worker health. While international regulatory bodies have emphasized lifecycle carbon reduction metrics, far less attention has been given to the potential occupational implications of fuel transitions. Ezeifeka’s work aims to fill this gap by producing data that aviation authorities, airport operators, aircraft manufacturers, and occupational health agencies can use to guide evidence- based decisions regarding SAF deployment.

Her interest in the topic reflects a broader scientific trajectory rooted in environmental health and exposure science. Building on her earlier training in soil science and environmental contamination, she brings an interdisciplinary lens that connects emissions behavior with real-world exposure pathways. Colleagues describe her research approach as structured, methodical, and guided by a strong commitment to worker safety.

The project also positions her as part of a growing network of African researchers contributing meaningfully to global environmental and technological transitions. Through her work on SAF emissions, she highlights the importance of including occupational health considerations in national and international aviation sustainability agendas. The findings from her study are expected to contribute to ongoing discussions by research boards, regulatory agencies, and technical committees working toward safer and cleaner aviation systems.

title: Air France KLM Martinair Cargo and DHL Global Forwarding renew strategic SAF ... - Payload Asia
description:
Air France KLM Martinair Cargo (AFKLMP Cargo) and DHL Global Forwarding (DHL) announced a new strategic partnership to advance the use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and accelerate the decarbonization of the air-freight industry.
This renewed agreement represents the largest annual SAF partnership AFKLMP Cargo has signed to date, reflecting not only its scale but also both companies’ long-term commitment to driving the industry’s transition toward low-carbon aviation.
Additional SAF volumes and related emissions reductions for 2026 and 2027 will be defined as the partnership progresses.
Since 2020, AFKLMP Cargo has been at the forefront of customer-oriented SAF programs, while DHL has embedded SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as a central lever for its climate targets.

text:
Air France KLM Martinair Cargo (AFKLMP Cargo) and DHL Global Forwarding (DHL) announced a new strategic partnership to advance the use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) and accelerate the decarbonization of the air-freight industry. Building on the success of their initial 2022–2024 agreement, both organisations have signed a new three-year framework contract covering 2025–2027.

For 2025 alone, the partnership includes a reduction target of 35,000 tons of CO₂-equivalent. This renewed agreement represents the largest annual SAF partnership AFKLMP Cargo has signed to date, reflecting not only its scale but also both companies’ long-term commitment to driving the industry’s transition toward low-carbon aviation. Additional SAF volumes and related emissions reductions for 2026 and 2027 will be defined as the partnership progresses.

Since 2020, AFKLMP Cargo has been at the forefront of customer-oriented SAF programs, while DHL has embedded SAF into its GoGreen Plus service as a central lever for its climate targets. Together, the companies bring industry-leading expertise, a shared vision, and a proven model for driving the adoption of low-carbon fuels.

The renewed contract builds on the success of a three-year agreement under which DHL reduced 77,595 tons of CO₂-equivalent between 2022 and 2024. This collaboration also enabled customers to make measurable progress toward their science-based carbon-reduction targets.

By extending their partnership, AFKLMP Cargo and DHL reaffirm the vital role of long-term collaboration in accelerating the aviation industry’s transition to low-carbon solutions.GertJan Roelands, SVP Commercial at Air France KLM Martinair Cargo, “We are proud to renew this partnership with DHL Global Forwarding, a clear sign of leadership. Our shared ambition and continued collaboration on SAF are fundamental to scaling the solutions needed to reduce the carbon footprint of the air freight industry. This new agreement reflects mutual trust, operational commitment, and a firm belief that only through close cooperation can we drive meaningful change across the air freight value chain.”

Henk Venema, EVP Global Airfreight at DHL Global Forwarding: “This framework agreement shows what collaborative decarbonization in air freight can look like. Emission Reduction Rights provide predictability, scalability, and transparency — three critical factors for sustainable aviation fuels to make a real impact within the market. Together with AFKLMP, we are establishing a foundation that can serve as a model for the entire industry.”
